message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Excess fluid administration increases capillary hydrostatic pressure, which can lead to edema. Capillary wall permeability, interstitial hydrostatic pressure, and interstitial oncotic pressure are not directly affected by fluid administration.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient received more fluid than the calculated requirement, which will increase capillary hydrostatic pressure. Increased capillary wall permeability will cause fluid leakage into the interstitial space, leading to edema. Interstitial hydrostatic pressure and interstitial oncotic pressure will not be affected by the excess fluid intake.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has received excess fluid and is at risk for fluid overload. Among the options, only capillary hydrostatic pressure is related to fluid overload, while the others are related to other factors, such as inflammation or lymphatic obstruction. Increased capillary hydrostatic pressure can lead to edema and fluid accumulation in the tissues.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Intravenous fluids increase the volume of blood plasma which would increase capillary hydrostatic pressure. Capillary wall permeability is not affected by fluid volume changes, and interstitial hydrostatic pressure and interstitial oncotic pressure are not directly related to fluid volume changes.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The excess fluid given intravenously will increase the capillary hydrostatic pressure. Capillary wall permeability, interstitial hydrostatic pressure, and interstitial oncotic pressure are not directly affected by the excess fluid administration.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The boy’s fluid intake is greater than his calculated fluid requirement, which can increase his blood volume and therefore, his capillary hydrostatic pressure. None of the other options are directly related to fluid intake.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Intravenous isotonic fluids increase the blood volume, which increases capillary hydrostatic pressure. Capillary wall permeability, interstitial hydrostatic pressure, and interstitial oncotic pressure are not directly affected by the increase in fluid volume.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The excessive intravenous fluids will increase the capillary hydrostatic pressure, leading to increased fluid movement out of the capillaries and into the interstitial space. None of the other options would be affected by this increase in fluid intake.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The boy is receiving more fluids than his calculated requirement, so capillary hydrostatic pressure is likely to be increased. This increased pressure can lead to edema formation and shifts of fluid from the intravascular space to the interstitial space. Capillary wall permeability, interstitial hydrostatic pressure, and interstitial oncotic pressure are not directly affected by the excess fluid infusion.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The boy’s intravenous fluid intake exceeds his calculated fluid requirement, indicating he may be experiencing increased capillary hydrostatic pressure. Excessive fluid intake can lead to fluid overload and increased capillary pressure. None of the other options would be directly affected by fluid intake.
